thread.title: Lauren_Mills published Lavendon sees strong performance, with no Brexit effect
thread.title_full: Lauren_Mills published Lavendon sees strong performance, with no Brexit effect

author: Lauren_Mills
title: Lauren_Mills published Lavendon sees strong performance, with no Brexit effect
text:
Comments (0) 
A company which rents out cherry pickers recorded strong performance in the first six months of its financial year. 
Lavendon, based in Lutterworth, said group revenues grew 13 per cent from £119.1 million to £144.2 million in the six months to June 30. 
Pre-tax profits for the period rose 10 per cent from £14.5 million to £15.9 million. 
Lavendon is Europe's market leader in the rental of high-level hydraulic platforms, otherwise known as mobile elevating work platforms, or MEWPs doe short, or simply cherry pickers. 
Over the years, Lavendon's cherry pickers have facilitated the coverage of all manner of international sporting events, state ceremonies, royal weddings and jubilee celebrations. 
Lavendon trades as Nationwide Platforms in the UK and its equipment can be spotted on vast construction and infrastructure projects all over the country. 
Its main customers are the big construction and facilities management groups such as Balfour Beatty, Carillion, Skanska, Kier and Mitie. This means it gets involved in some pretty impressive, high-profile projects including Lord's in London, New Street Station, Birmingham and the Heathrow TB2 project. 
In France, it helps out with the maintenance of The Louvre, in Paris. 
In addition to its 26 depots in the UK, Lavendon has six depots in France and also operates out of Belgium and Germany. 
It also has a well-established business in the Middle East, in Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. 
Read more: Lavendon CEO Don Kenny on mission to raise company's share price 
The company said it saw strong rental revenue growth in its home market as well as France and Saudi Arabia. 
Lavendon chief executive Don Kenny said: "The group's trading performance in the first half has seen the delivery of strong revenue growth that has driven further improvements in our profits and operational cash flows. This growth has built upon the momentum established within the business towards the end of 2015 with the UK, Middle East and France being the primary drivers. 
"Our growth reflects our strategic fleet investment decisions in 2015 and the actions taken in the first half to optimise our fleet deliveries and improve our operational processes. We haven't seen any impact post-Brexit. 
"The restructuring of our German business is progressing as planned and is on track to be operational in quarter four. The group's strong operational cash flows and strength of our balance sheet enables us to develop our market positions with investment, underpinning the positive momentum created within the business, whilst at the same time remaining within our preferred debt leverage range." 
He said the UK's decision to leave the EU has not had any impact on the business. 
He said: "Trading since the half year has continued to be in line with our expectations and, whilst mindful of the recent increased economic uncertainty, the board remains confident of making further progress in the second half and delivering on its expectations for 2016."
